page.title: 05HISTORY OF CROSFIELDS SCHOOL
page.content: The earliest date of Crosfields was in 1643 when King Charles 1st stayed there and said that he had had a " good rest".That building was knocked down and a new one called "Goodrest" was built in 1820 by Sir Francis Englefield. By 1945 it belonged to a Colonel Beel and was used as a convalescent home for soldiers injured in the 2nd World War.In 1946 it was bought by Leighton Park School to be used as a Junior School.This continued until 1957 when it became a separate entity.The name "Crosfields" was derived from the man who founded it, Hugh Crosfield.The school emblem of 6 oakleaves is taken fom Marlbrough school which has closed down. In 1985 there were 260 boys, 20 teachers and 8 other staff.
